author: sky.cactus
content: <@689161464829050960> I think the attack being discussed basically boils down to "someone who can control the contract deployment contract can compromise the contract".

author: sky.cactus
content: Am I incorrect (haven't thought about it deeply) that the same attack exists without multiple chains involved?

author: sky.cactus
content: Deploy an invoker in a way that allows you to redeploy it, then once you have collected a bunch of signatures you redeploy a malicious invoker of the same address?

author: sky.cactus
content: I guess the difference is that the invoker in the same-chain scenario would need a self-destruct mechanism, while in the cross-chain attack you don't need a self-destruct mechanism.

author: sky.cactus
content: So I suppose that particular vector becomes a bit easier to integrate in the multi-chain scenario.

author: lightclient
content: I think it's mainly about the multi-chain scenario. Be able to redeploy an invoker is non-starter IMO. To me, that is a fully insecure invoker. But doing a multi-chain deployment is a little more sneaky because the mainnet deployment can look normal (except when you really dig into the deployment tx) and then they could deploy a different invoker to the same address on another chain
